Storm before the storm.full_title: The Storm Before the Storm: The Beginning of the End of the Roman Republic
Storm before the storm.author: Mike Duncan
Storm before the storm.plot_summary: Mike Duncan chronicles the tumultuous era before the fall of the Roman Republic, covering the period from 146-78 BC. The book examines how political polarization, economic inequality, and the erosion of democratic norms led to the unraveling of Rome's republican government.
fun_facts: Mike Duncan is best known for his wildly popular podcast 'The History of Rome', which ran from 2007 to 2012
The book draws direct parallels between the decline of the Roman Republic and modern American politics
Duncan followed this with another hit podcast, 'Revolutions', covering political upheavals throughout history

Oranges.author: John McPhee
Oranges.plot_summary: John McPhee takes readers on a fascinating deep dive into the world of oranges, covering everything from the fruit's botanical origins to the global orange juice industry. What began as a magazine piece became a beloved classic of creative nonfiction.
fun_facts: McPhee originally wrote this as an article for The New Yorker, but kept finding so much material it became a full book
John McPhee is considered one of the pioneers of creative nonfiction and won the Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction in 1999
The book covers the entire history of oranges from ancient China to modern Florida

Alchemy of Air.full_title: The Alchemy of Air: A Jewish Genius, a Doomed Tycoon, and the Scientific Discovery That Fed the World but Fueled the Rise of Hitler
Alchemy of Air.author: Thomas Hager
Alchemy of Air.plot_summary: Thomas Hager tells the story of Fritz Haber and Carl Bosch, who discovered how to extract nitrogen from the air to create synthetic fertilizer. Their invention saved millions from starvation but also enabled the production of explosives and chemical weapons that fueled two world wars.
fun_facts: The Haber-Bosch process is responsible for feeding roughly half the world's current population
Fritz Haber won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1918, despite his role in developing chemical weapons used in WWI
Haber was Jewish and was eventually forced to flee Nazi Germany, dying in exile in 1934

Chip War.full_title: Chip War: The Fight for the World's Most Critical Technology
Chip War.author: Chris Miller
Chip War.plot_summary: Chris Miller traces the history of the semiconductor industry from its origins in the Cold War to the present-day geopolitical struggle over chip manufacturing. The book reveals how microchips have become the world's most critical resource and why control of the supply chain is reshaping global power.
fun_facts: The book won the 2023 Financial Times Business Book of the Year Award
TSMC in Taiwan produces over 90% of the world's most advanced semiconductors
Chris Miller is an associate professor of international history at Tufts University
awards: Financial Times Business Book of the Year 2023

Three Body Problem.author: Liu Cixin
Three Body Problem.plot_summary: Set against the backdrop of China's Cultural Revolution, a secret military project sends signals into space and makes first contact with an alien civilization on the brink of destruction. As the aliens plan their migration to Earth, different factions on Earth form in response, some welcoming and some opposing the invasion.
fun_facts: Liu Cixin is the first Asian author to win the Hugo Award for Best Novel
The English translation by Ken Liu was published in 2014, six years after the Chinese original
Netflix adapted the trilogy into a major TV series in 2024
The novel was originally serialized in Science Fiction World magazine in 2006

Sea of Tranquility.author: Emily St. John Mandel
Sea of Tranquility.plot_summary: A genre-defying novel that moves between the forests of Vancouver Island in 1912, a moon colony in the year 2401, and other times in between. Characters across centuries are connected by a strange anomaly in time, and an investigator from the future must determine if they are living in a simulation.
fun_facts: Mandel is also the author of 'Station Eleven', which was adapted into an HBO Max series
The novel connects thematically to her previous books 'Station Eleven' and 'The Glass Hotel'
Despite being only 259 pages, the book spans over 500 years of human history

Piranesi.author: Susanna Clarke
Piranesi.plot_summary: Piranesi lives in a vast, mysterious House filled with endless halls of statues, where ocean tides wash through the lower floors and clouds drift through the upper ones. His only companion is the Other, who visits to conduct research. As Piranesi begins to question his reality, he uncovers secrets about the House and his own identity.
fun_facts: The book won the 2021 Women's Prize for Fiction
Susanna Clarke spent years battling chronic fatigue syndrome between her debut 'Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell' (2004) and 'Piranesi'
The title references Giovanni Battista Piranesi, an 18th-century Italian artist known for his etchings of imaginary prisons

The Wager.full_title: The Wager: A Tale of Shipwreck, Mutiny and Murder
The Wager.author: David Grann
The Wager.plot_summary: In 1742, a British warship called the Wager wrecked on a desolate island off the coast of Patagonia. The surviving crew descended into warring factions, mutiny, and murder. When a handful of survivors finally made it back to England, each told a wildly different story of what happened.
fun_facts: David Grann is also the author of 'Killers of the Flower Moon', adapted into a Martin Scorsese film
Martin Scorsese acquired the film rights to 'The Wager' before the book was even published
The real HMS Wager was part of Commodore Anson's ill-fated voyage around the world in 1740

As I lay Dying.author: William Faulkner
As I lay Dying.plot_summary: The Bundren family embarks on a grueling journey across the Mississippi countryside to bury their matriarch, Addie, in her hometown of Jefferson. Told through 15 different narrators, the novel reveals each family member's secret motivations, grief, and desperation during the odyssey.
fun_facts: Faulkner claimed he wrote the entire novel in six weeks while working night shifts at a power plant
The title comes from Book XI of Homer's Odyssey, spoken by the ghost of Agamemnon
Faulkner considered it his 'tour de force' and his personal favorite among his novels

YellowFace.author: R.F. Kuang
YellowFace.plot_summary: After witnessing fellow author Athena Liu's sudden death, struggling white writer June Hayward steals Athena's unpublished manuscript about Chinese laborers in WWI and publishes it as her own. As the book becomes a bestseller, June spirals into paranoia, deception, and self-justification while facing accusations of cultural theft.
fun_facts: R.F. Kuang wrote this novel while completing her PhD at Yale in East Asian Languages and Literatures
The book was a Reese's Book Club pick in 2023
Kuang was only 25 when Yellowface was published, and she already had four bestselling fantasy novels to her name

Prophet Song.author: Paul Lynch
Prophet Song.plot_summary: When Ireland slides into totalitarianism under a newly empowered security force, scientist Eilish Stack watches as her trade-unionist husband is taken by the secret police. As civil liberties erode and violence escalates, she must decide how far she will go to protect her four children.
fun_facts: The novel won the 2023 Booker Prize, making Lynch the fourth Irish author to win the award
The book is written in a distinctive stream-of-consciousness style with almost no paragraph breaks
Lynch deliberately set the story in Ireland to show that authoritarianism can take hold anywhere, not just in distant countries

The Human Stain.author: Philip Roth
The Human Stain.plot_summary: Coleman Silk, a 71-year-old classics professor, is forced to resign after being falsely accused of making a racist remark. As narrator Nathan Zuckerman investigates Silk's story, he uncovers a secret that has defined Silk's entire life: a hidden identity that challenges everything others believed about him.
fun_facts: The novel was inspired by the real-life story of Anatole Broyard, a literary critic who passed as white for most of his life
It was adapted into a 2003 film starring Anthony Hopkins and Nicole Kidman
The Human Stain is the final book in Roth's American Trilogy, following 'American Pastoral' and 'I Married a Communist'

Ghost Fleet.full_title: Ghost Fleet: A Novel of the Next World War
Ghost Fleet.author: P.W. Singer and August Cole
Ghost Fleet.plot_summary: In a frighteningly realistic near-future scenario, China launches a surprise attack on the United States using advanced cyberwarfare and space weapons. America must rely on a ragtag fleet of decommissioned warships and a new generation of guerrilla fighters to mount a desperate counterattack.
fun_facts: P.W. Singer is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and adviser to the US military
The book was required reading at the Pentagon and was used in military war-gaming exercises
Every technology and weapon in the novel is based on real systems that either exist or are in development

Project Hail Mary.author: Andy Weir
Project Hail Mary.plot_summary: Ryland Grace wakes up alone on a spaceship with no memory of who he is or why he's there. As his memory slowly returns, he realizes he's humanity's last hope, sent on a desperate mission to solve an extinction-level threat to Earth. An unexpected encounter in deep space changes everything.
fun_facts: Ryan Gosling is set to star in the film adaptation, directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller
Andy Weir sold the film rights before the book was even published
The novel features one of the most beloved alien characters in modern science fiction
Weir is also the author of 'The Martian', which he originally self-published as a serial on his blog

All the sinners bleed.author: S.A. Cosby
All the sinners bleed.plot_summary: Titus Crown, the first Black sheriff of a small Virginia town, investigates a school shooting that uncovers a string of cold-case murders connected to a secret group hiding behind religion. As Titus digs deeper, he must confront the racism and violence woven into his community's history.
fun_facts: S.A. Cosby worked as a bouncer and a truck driver before becoming a full-time writer
The novel was a New York Times bestseller and appeared on numerous 'Best of 2023' lists
Cosby is known for pioneering the 'country noir' or Southern noir subgenre with his Blacktop Wasteland and Razorblade Tears

Freedom.author: Jonathan Franzen
Freedom.plot_summary: The Berglund family appears to be the ideal progressive household in St. Paul, Minnesota, but behind closed doors their lives unravel through marital betrayal, political disillusionment, and generational conflict. Spanning decades, the novel examines how personal freedom can become both a blessing and a curse.
fun_facts: The novel was famously featured on the cover of Time magazine with the headline 'Great American Novelist'
Franzen's feud with Oprah Winfrey over his novel 'The Corrections' became literary legend, but they reconciled and Freedom became an Oprah's Book Club pick
The novel was written over nine years and went through multiple complete rewrites

Elmer Gantry.author: Sinclair Lewis
Elmer Gantry.plot_summary: Elmer Gantry is a charismatic but deeply hypocritical man who rises through the ranks of American evangelical Christianity. Despite his womanizing, drinking, and complete lack of genuine faith, he uses his charm and oratory skills to become one of the most powerful preachers in the country.
fun_facts: The novel was banned in several cities and condemned by clergy across America upon publication
Sinclair Lewis was the first American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature (1930)
The 1960 film adaptation starring Burt Lancaster won three Academy Awards
Lewis reportedly attended dozens of church services and revival meetings as research

High Rise.author: J.G. Ballard
High Rise.plot_summary: The residents of a luxury high-rise apartment building in London gradually descend into tribal warfare as the building's infrastructure begins to fail. Class divisions between the floors escalate from petty disputes to full-blown savagery, revealing the thin veneer of civilization.
fun_facts: Ballard was inspired by the real Barbican Estate and Trellick Tower in London
The novel was adapted into a 2015 film starring Tom Hiddleston
Ballard predicted many aspects of modern gated communities and luxury living isolationism
The famous opening line is: 'Later, as he sat on his balcony eating the dog...'

The Water Dancer.author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
The Water Dancer.plot_summary: Hiram Walker is born into slavery on a Virginia plantation but possesses a mysterious supernatural power connected to water and memory. After a near-drowning awakens this gift, Hiram joins the Underground Railroad and discovers that his power may be the key to liberating his people.
fun_facts: This was Ta-Nehisi Coates's debut novel; he was previously known for his nonfiction, particularly 'Between the World and Me'
The novel was Oprah Winfrey's first pick for her relaunched Apple TV+ book club
Coates drew on the real history of the Underground Railroad and the plantation system in Virginia

Who is Government.author: Unknown (Discussion Material)
Who is Government.plot_summary: Discussion material exploring the nature of government, its roles, and its relationship with citizens. Used as a book club selection to facilitate political and philosophical debate.
fun_facts: This appears to be discussion material rather than a traditionally published book
It was proposed by member Faulkner for the Drunk Book Club

Kim.author: Rudyard Kipling
Kim.plot_summary: Kimball O'Hara, an orphaned son of an Irish soldier, grows up as a street urchin in Lahore, India. He becomes the disciple of a Tibetan lama on a spiritual quest while simultaneously being recruited into the British secret service's 'Great Game' of espionage against Russia.
fun_facts: Kipling won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907, the first English-language writer to receive the honor
The phrase 'The Great Game' for Central Asian espionage was popularized by this novel
Kim is often considered Kipling's masterpiece and one of the greatest novels about India
The novel draws heavily on Kipling's own childhood in India

Careless People.full_title: Careless People: Murder, Mayhem, and the Invention of The Great Gatsby
Careless People.author: Sarah Churchwell
Careless People.plot_summary: Sarah Churchwell interweaves the real-life story of F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald with the unsolved 1922 Hall-Mills double murder case, showing how both influenced the creation of The Great Gatsby. The book is part literary detective story, part Jazz Age history.
fun_facts: The title comes from a famous passage in The Great Gatsby: 'They were careless people, Tom and Daisy'
Churchwell is a professor of American literature at the University of London
The Hall-Mills murder case she investigates was one of the most sensational unsolved crimes of the 1920s

The Safekeep.author: Yael van der Wouden
The Safekeep.plot_summary: In the 1960s Netherlands, Isabel lives an orderly, solitary life in her family's countryside home. When her brother's brash girlfriend Eva moves in, Isabel's carefully controlled world begins to unravel as she discovers an unexpected attraction to Eva and confronts buried truths about her family's home and its wartime history.
fun_facts: The novel was longlisted for the 2024 Booker Prize
Yael van der Wouden was born in Israel and raised in the Netherlands
The Safekeep is her debut novel and explores the legacy of WWII property seizures in the Netherlands
The book has been praised for its tension and slow-burn romantic elements
